TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract sealed beforefieldinit DragDrop extends System.Object
public ref class DragDrop abstract sealed

Docs.summary: Provides helper methods and fields for initiating drag-and-drop operations, including a method to begin a drag-and-drop operation, and facilities for adding and removing drag-and-drop related event handlers.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Drag-and-drop commonly refers to a method of data transfer that involves using a mouse (or some other pointing device) to select one or more objects, dragging these objects over some desired drop target in the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_ui](~/includes/tlasharptla-ui-md.md)], and dropping them. A drag-and-drop operation is analogous to a copy (or cut)-and-paste operation that is used to transfer data from one object or application to another. Drag-and-drop operations typically involve two parties: a drag source from which the dragged data originates and a drop target which receives the dropped data. The events and methods required for drag-and-drop operations are defined in the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop> class. The drag-and-drop events are attached events that can be attached to any <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> or <xref:System.Windows.ContentElement>. The drag source and drop target may be UI elements in the same application or in different applications. However, the drop target must know how to process the data being passed by the drag source.
> [!NOTE] > The <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> and <xref:System.Windows.ContentElement> classes contain aliases for the drag-and-drop events so that the events appear in the class members list when these classes are inherited as a base class. When you attach an event handler to a drag-and-drop event on one of these classes, the handler is attached to the underlying <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop> event and they receive the same instance of event data. For example, see <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.Drop?displayProperty=nameWithType>.
The drag source initiates a drag-and-drop operation by calling the static <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DoDragDrop%2A> method and passing the transferred data to it. An element typically handles the following events when it is a drag source:
- <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.GiveFeedback>
- <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.QueryContinueDrag>
An element typically handles the following events when it is a drop target:
- <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DragEnter>
- <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DragLeave>
- <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DragOver>
- <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.Drop>
For more information and examples, see [Drag and Drop Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/drag-and-drop-overview.md).

MemberSignature.Value: public static void AddDragEnterHandler (System.Windows.DependencyObject element, System.Windows.DragEventHandler handler);
.method public static hidebysig void AddDragEnterHandler(class System.Windows.DependencyObject element, class System.Windows.DragEventHandler handler) cil managed
Public Shared Sub AddDragEnterHandler (element As DependencyObject, handler As DragEventHandler)
public: static void AddDragEnterHandler(System::Windows::DependencyObject ^ element, System::Windows::DragEventHandler ^ handler);

Docs.param: The dependency object (a or ) to which to add the event handler.
A delegate that references the handler method to be added.
Docs.summary: Adds a event handler to a specified dependency object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DragEnter> event occurs when an object is dragged into the element's bounds.
This method adds a handler for the bubbling version of the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DragEnter> event. To add a handler for the tunneling version of this event, see <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.AddPreviewDragEnterHandler%2A>.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.PreviewQueryContinueDrag> event occurs during a drag-and-drop operation, and enables the drag source to determine whether the drag-and-drop operation should be canceled.
This method adds a handler for the tunneling version of the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.PreviewQueryContinueDrag> event. To add a handler for the bubbling version of this event, see <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.AddQueryContinueDragHandler%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Windows.DragDropEffects DoDragDrop (System.Windows.DependencyObject dragSource, object data, System.Windows.DragDropEffects allowedEffects);

.method public static hidebysig valuetype System.Windows.DragDropEffects DoDragDrop(class System.Windows.DependencyObject dragSource, object data, valuetype System.Windows.DragDropEffects allowedEffects) cil managed
Public Shared Function DoDragDrop (dragSource As DependencyObject, data As Object, allowedEffects As DragDropEffects) As DragDropEffects
public: static System::Windows::DragDropEffects DoDragDrop(System::Windows::DependencyObject ^ dragSource, System::Object ^ data, System::Windows::DragDropEffects allowedEffects);

Docs.param: A reference to the dependency object that is the source of the data being dragged.
A data object that contains the data being dragged.
One of the values that specifies permitted effects of the drag-and-drop operation.
Docs.summary: Initiates a drag-and-drop operation.
Docs.returns: One of the values that specifies the final effect that was performed during the drag-and-drop operation.

remarks.format:
## Remarks It is the responsibility of your application to determine when a drag occurs, and then initiate the drag-and-drop operation. Typically, this is when a <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.MouseDown> and <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.MouseMove> sequence of events occurs over the element to be dragged. You initiate the drag-and-drop operation by calling the static <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DoDragDrop%2A> method and passing the transferred data to it. The <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DoDragDrop%2A> method will automatically wrap the data in a <xref:System.Windows.DataObject> if necessary. For greater control over the data format, you can wrap the data in a <xref:System.Windows.DataObject> before passing it to the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DoDragDrop%2A> method.
The value returned from the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DoDragDrop%2A> method is the value of the <xref:System.Windows.DragEventArgs.Effects%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property set in the drop target’s <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.Drop> event handler. If the return value does not match one of the `allowedEffects` specified in the call to <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DoDragDrop%2A>, the drag-and-drop operation is not performed.
## Examples The following example shows how to initiate a drag-and-drop operation from the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.MouseMove> event handler of an <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Ellipse> element to make it a drag source. The transferred data is the string representation of the ellipse’s <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Shape.Fill%2A> property. The data is passed to the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DoDragDrop%2A> method as a string and is automatically wrapped in a <xref:System.Windows.DataObject>.
[!code-csharp[DragDropSnippets#DoDragDrop](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/dragdropsnippets/cs/mainwindow.xaml.cs#dodragdrop)] [!code-vb[DragDropSnippets#DoDragDrop](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/dragdropsnippets/vb/mainwindow.xaml.vb#dodragdrop)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DragEnter> event occurs when an object is dragged into the element's bounds.
This method removes a handler for the bubbling version of the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DragEnter> event. To remove a handler for the tunneling version of this event, see <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.RemovePreviewDragEnterHandler%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: public static void RemoveDragLeaveHandler (System.Windows.DependencyObject element, System.Windows.DragEventHandler handler);
.method public static hidebysig void RemoveDragLeaveHandler(class System.Windows.DependencyObject element, class System.Windows.DragEventHandler handler) cil managed
Public Shared Sub RemoveDragLeaveHandler (element As DependencyObject, handler As DragEventHandler)
public: static void RemoveDragLeaveHandler(System::Windows::DependencyObject ^ element, System::Windows::DragEventHandler ^ handler);

Docs.param: The dependency object (a or ) from which to remove the event handler.
A delegate that references the handler method to be removed.
Docs.summary: Removes a event handler from a specified dependency object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DragLeave> event occurs when an object is dragged out of the element's bounds.
This method removes a handler for the bubbling version of the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.DragLeave> event. To remove a handler for the tunneling version of this event, see <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.RemovePreviewDragLeaveHandler%2A>.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.Drop> event occurs when an object is dropped within an element's bounds.
This method removes a handler for the bubbling version of the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.Drop> event. To remove a handler for the tunneling version of this event, see <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.RemovePreviewDropHandler%2A>.

This method removes a handler for the tunneling version of the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.PreviewGiveFeedback> event. To remove a handler for the bubbling version of this event, see <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.RemoveGiveFeedbackHandler%2A>.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.PreviewQueryContinueDrag> event occurs during a drag-and-drop operation, and enables the drag source to determine whether the drag-and-drop operation should be canceled.
This method removes a handler for the tunneling version of the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.PreviewQueryContinueDrag> event. To remove a handler for the bubbling version of this event, see <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.RemoveQueryContinueDragHandler%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: public static void RemoveQueryContinueDragHandler (System.Windows.DependencyObject element, System.Windows.QueryContinueDragEventHandler handler);

Docs.param: The dependency object (a or ) from which to remove the event handler.
A delegate that references the handler method to be removed.
Docs.summary: Removes a event handler from a specified dependency object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.QueryContinueDrag> event occurs during a drag-and-drop operation, and enables the drag source to determine whether the drag-and-drop operation should be canceled.
This method removes a handler for the bubbling version of the <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.QueryContinueDrag> event. To remove a handler for the tunneling version of this event, see <xref:System.Windows.DragDrop.RemovePreviewQueryContinueDragHandler%2A>.
